conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with three logs stacked on the ground.
Three logs A, B, and C are stacked with A on top, forming an isosceles triangle with a top angle of 120 degrees.
Static friction is at its maximum and equal to sliding friction; ignore friction between logs.
Base angles of the isosceles triangle are 30 degrees each.
Plan to draw a free-body diagram for each log.
For log A, mg = N_B + N_C and N_B = N_C, so each normal force is mg/2.
For log B, consider its weight, normal force from the ground, and force from log A.
Force from log A on log B is along the line connecting their centers.
Determine normal force from the ground on logs B and C.
Static friction force is μN, where μ is the coefficient of friction.
Forces on log B include weight mg, normal force from the ground, and force from log A.
Consider forces at the centers O1, O2, and O3.
Distance between O1 and O2 is 2R, and between O2 and O3 is 2R.
Vertical distance from O1 to line O2-O3 is R√3.
Distance from O1 to O2 is 4R/√3.
Horizontal distance between O2 and O3 is 2R√3.
Forces on log A include weight mg and normal forces from B and C.
Normal force from log A on log B is mg/2 at 30 degrees above horizontal.
